Notes.Text:
Xen was updated to fix two security issues:

    * CVE-2015-3456: A buffer overflow in the floppy drive emulation, which
      could be used to carry out denial of service attacks or potential
      code execution against the host. This vulnerability is also known as
      VENOM.
    * CVE-2015-3340: An information leak through XEN_DOMCTL_gettscinfo().
      (XSA-132)

Security Issues:

    * CVE-2015-3456
      <http://cve.mitre.org/cgi-bin/cvename.cgi?name=CVE-2015-3456>
    * CVE-2015-3340
      <http://cve.mitre.org/cgi-bin/cvename.cgi?name=CVE-2015-3340>

Vulnerabilities.Description: Xen 4.2.x through 4.5.x does not initialize certain fields, which allows certain remote service domains to obtain sensitive information from memory via a (1) XEN_DOMCTL_gettscinfo or (2) XEN_SYSCTL_getdomaininfolist request.

Vulnerabilities.Description: The Floppy Disk Controller (FDC) in QEMU, as used in Xen 4.5.x and earlier and KVM, allows local guest users to cause a denial of service (out-of-bounds write and guest crash) or possibly execute arbitrary code via the (1) FD_CMD_READ_ID, (2) FD_CMD_DRIVE_SPECIFICATION_COMMAND, or other unspecified commands, aka VENOM.
